bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, December 26, 1939

div1.p: Hutchison informs Hench that he is to be the keynote speaker for Washington and Jefferson College Founders' Day. He muses whether Moran and Kissinger should attend as well.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, December 26, 1939

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
December 26, 1939

div1.p:
In the first place, thank you for the check
for one hundred and fifty dollars for your part in
our Chemistry Building. This is a swell thing for
you to do and I think I can look over the long list of
contributions and find no other which means as much
to me personally as this one from you and Mary. You
can well understand the reason for that and the truth
of it.

I am dictating this letter on Saturday before
Christmas though it will not be transcribed until
Tuesday after Christmas. This morning came your
special delivery letter. We would be delighted to have
the London Pictorial just as you suggest. Our children
would be interested in it and it would keep us in
touch with the English aspect of the war in which we
are intensely interested. I have left your letter at
the house in order that Harriet may read it and so
I may not have the name of that supplement correct.
Nevertheless we would love to have it. There is
nothing that we would rather have and we will be delight-
ed to receive it as a gift from you and Mary.

In regard to the Founders' Day, I think that
your fear of your material being an anticlimax is not
well founded. The plan which I am shortly to present
to the Board of Trustees for this Founders' day program
is as follows. On Friday evening we would have your
lecture on the background of Doctor Lazear's work as an
introduction to the presentation of “Yellow Jack.”
You can see how this would start the program beautifully
and make the play of “Yellow Jack” even more interesting.
If you have moving pictures or still pictures, they
would fit perfectly, and because this would be the
kickoff in the entire program there would be no slightest
danger of it having the effect of an anticlimax. It seems
to me that this would be a perfect setup on Friday even-
ing. Then on Saturday morning would be the dedication
exercises of the Chemistry Building with the address being
made by Doctor Sawyer. In the evening would be the Home-
coming Dinner with the address being made, perhaps by
Doctor Mohler, or whatever his name is, who is dean of
Jefferson Medical School. This depends upon two things in
my thinking. In the first place, it depends upon whether
we discover him to be a reasonably good speaker. I have
written to several of our students in the medical school to
Doctor Philip S. Hench
-2-
December 26, 1939
see what their judgment is about that and am looking
forward, of course, to the information which you
discover. In the second place, it would depend upon
the successful rapprochement of Washington and
Jefferson and Jefferson Medical School in the matter
of the famous stolen portrait which I hope may be
regained from Jefferson Medical School and presented
to this College at that dinner.

This plan was ready for presentation to our
Executive Committee yesterday but other business
crowded it out, and will be taken under consideration
by the trustees during the first or second week in
January.

I suppose that you are familiar with the
story of O'Hara, or whatever his real name is, the one
in Cuba, which appeared in the Saturday Evening Post
in August of this year. I have sent for more copies of
this, and if you did not see it please let me know.
I want you to have one. He appears to be a rather
successful business man down there and may occasionally
come to the United States.

If you are going over to see him on your
vacation, I think you ought to explore the possibilities
of inducing him to come up on business at the time of
this Founders' Day. Incidentally, we are setting this
Founders' Day for Saturday, October the twenty-sixth,
and you should put the date down now and have it in mind.
Perhaps this man in Cuba will have a business trip to
America next fall and could so plan it that he could
come for these exercises. We would devise some way of
honoring him. I do not suppose that under any possible
stretch of imagination we could make it into a degree,
though we could do something equally effective so far
as he is concerned, possibly. I question whether we could
finance the cost of bringing him from Cuba for the
exercises, but we can make it a very nice occasion for
him if he could come.

You and I can take up later the possibility
of bringing Kissinger from Indiana which would not be such
a great expense and which might be possible. The
article in the Saturday Evening Post indicates that six
or seven of the men who took part in that experiment
are still living if I remember correctly. If I get these
Doctor Philip S. Hench
-3-
December 26, 1939
copies I will send you one whether you have seen it or
not, and without waiting to hear from you.

In summary, therefore, I think anything you
can gather together will be right. I believe any
pictures you can get, particularly moving pictures, would
be very effective and I think you ought to count on
doing a talk on the background of the Lazear work at the
“Yellow Jack” play event on Friday night. This seems to
me to be the right setup.

Give our love to Mary. I am interested
to know that your mother will be here during the Christmas
holidays and I will go in to see her.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
